facts.text: This is a Criminal Appeal No. 53 of 1968 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 53 of 1968. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 30, 1967 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No 1734 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 30, 1967 of the Patna High Court in Criminal Revision No 1734 of 1967. Ganpat Rai, for the appellant.

facts.text: Patna High Court dismissed the criminal revision on October 30, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Ganpat Rai, for the appellant. Goburdhun and Ram Das Chadha, for respondent No.1. Goburdhun, for the respondent No. 2. The Judgment of the Court was delivered Ray, J.-This is an appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order of the Patna High Court dated 30 October, 1967 dismissing an application in the criminal revisional jurisdiction

facts.text: First Additional Judicial Commissioner, Ranchi upheld conviction on 31 July, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: ...dated 30 October, 1967 dismissing an application in the criminal revisional jurisdiction against the judgment of the First Additional Judicial Commissioner, Ranchi dated 31 July, 1967 upholding the conviction and sentence passed by the Judicial Magistrate, First Class, Ranchi.

facts.text: Appellant convicted under section 500 IPC by Judicial Magistrate First Class Ranchi and sentenced to fine Rs 500 or 3 months simple imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was convicted under section 500 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced to pay a fine of Rs. 500 and in default to suffer simple imprisonment for three months.

facts.text: Proceeding under section 144 CrPC between respondents and appellant regarding land in village Hatma, district Ranchi, Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: There was a proceeding under section-144 of the Criminal Procedure Code between the respondents and the appellant regarding some land in the village Hatma in the district of Ranchi in the State of Bihar.

facts.text: Land recorded in names of Karma Ahir and Faizu Ahir.

anchor.surface_text: The land was recorded in the names of two brothers Karma Ahir and Faizu Ahir.

facts.text: Appellant is grandson of Karma Ahir.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the grandson of Karma Ahir.

facts.text: Faizu Ahir had two sons by first wife who died during his lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: Faizu Ahir had two sons by his first wife. Both of them died during his lifetime.

facts.text: Respondent and his brother Sahdeo Mahto claimed land as sons of Faizu Ahir by second wife.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent and his brother Sahdeo Mahto claimed the land as sons of Faizu Ahir by his second wife.

facts.text: Appellant described Basdeo Mahto and Sahdeo Mahto as illegitimate sons of Faizu Ahir born of concubine in showing cause.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in showing cause described Basdeo Mahto and his brother Sahdeo Mahto as illegitimate sons of Faizu Ahir having been born of concubine.

facts.text: Appellant's lawyer submitted before Sub-Divisional Officer in November 1965 that respondent and brother were illegitimate sons born of concubine; complainant's brother-in-law present.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case was that the complainants brother-in law was present in the court of the Sub-Divisional Officer in the month of November, 1965 when the appellants lawyer submitted before the Sub Divisional Officer that the respondent and his brother were illegitimate sons of Faizu Ahir having been born of concubine.

facts.text: Complainant obtained certified copy of written statement filed by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The complainant then obtained a certified copy of the written statement field by the appellant.

facts.text: Complainant filed the complaint.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the complainant filed the complaint.

facts.text: Faizu Ahir married Mst. Sauni, a widow, in Sagai form more than 40 years ago according to Yadav community custom; she lived as wedded wife, treated as such.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the complainant was that Faizu Ahir had married Mst. Sauni, who was a widow, in Sagai form more than 40 years ago according to the custom prevalent among the Yadav community. She was living with Faizu Ahir as his wedded wife and was treated as such by the community.

facts.text: Respondent and brother born long after marriage, legitimate sons of Faizu Ahir.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant and his brother were born long after the marriage and were the legitimate sons of Faizu Ahir.

facts.text: Appellant made statements to humiliate and defame respondent and brother.

anchor.surface_text: The complainant alleged that the appellant made the statements with a view to humilating and defaming the appellant and his brother.

facts.text: Appellant pleaded not guilty; defence that statements true and necessary to disclose as respondents claimed property without right.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant pleaded not guilty. His defence was that the statements made in the written statements were true. The appellant further said that he had to disclose this fact as the respondent and his brother dishonestly claimed the property to which they had no right.

facts.text: Court finding: Faizu Ahir married Sauni in Sagai form.

anchor.surface_text: The findings of fact are these. Faizu Ahir married Sauni in Sagai form.

facts.text: Court finding: Respondent was legitimate son of Faizu Ahir.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was the legitimate son of Faizu Ahir.

facts.text: Statements in written statement false and defamatory.

anchor.surface_text: On these findings the Magistrate held that the statements in the written statement were false and defamatory.

facts.text: Appellant did not lead oral evidence to show good faith.

anchor.surface_text: The Additional Judicial Commissioner held that the appellant did not lead any oral evidence to show that he acted in good faith.

facts.text: Appellant relied on certified copy of deposition of respondent in GR 775/65.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant relied on a certified copy of the deposition of the respondent in case No. GR. 775/65.

facts.text: In GR 775/65, respondent said he did not know if Faizu kept concubine and if he was son of concubine.

anchor.surface_text: There the respondent was asked a question in that case as to whether Faizu Ahir had kept a concubine and whether he was the son of that concubine. The respondent replied that he did not know that Faizu Ahir kept a concubine and that he was the son of the concubine.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner held respondent's evidence sufficient denial.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner held that the entire evidence of the respondent in that case was that Puran and, Jitu were his step, brothers and the answers were sufficient to show that there was a denial of the suggestion that he was the son of the concubine.

facts.text: No evidence that appellant made enquiry before imputation.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by these tests laid down in the rulings of this Court the findings of fact in the present case are that there is no evidence to show that before making the imputation the appellant had made any enquiry in good faith and the appellant had not shown due care and attention before making the imputation.

facts.text: Appellant related to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: By reason of the findings of fact that the appellant did not act with care and caution and secondly that the appellant was related to the respondent

facts.text: Question in s144 proceeding was possession of land, not title.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the question was who was in possession of the land. It would not be open to a person to deny or resist possession in proceeding under section 144 of the Criminal procedure Code by hurling defamatory invectives

facts.text: High Court dismissed revision application.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was justified in dismissing the revision application and not interfering with the judgment and order of the Judicial Commissioner.

facts.text: Land in village Hatma, Ranchi district, Bihar state.

anchor.surface_text: some land in the village Hatma in the district of Ranchi in the State of Bihar.

concepts.unlisted_description: Punishment for defamation: simple imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both.

anchor.surface_text: Section 499 deals with defamation. Section 500 prescribes punishment for defamation. There are nine exceptions
The relevant provision in the present case is the Ninth Exception to section 499 of the Indian Penal Code. Section 499 deals with defamation.

concepts.interpretation: No defamation if imputation made in good faith for protection of interests of the maker, another person, or public good. Good faith requires due care, attention, enquiry with rational basis, not mere belief. Protection requires bona fide communication on subject of interest or duty for communicator and recipient.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: on is made has a companyresponding interest or duty. The illustration  a  to the Ninth Exception typifies that idea A, a shopkeeper, says to B, who ma

concepts.unlisted_description: Imputation on character in good faith for protection of interest or public good.

anchor.surface_text: Good faith is a question of fact. So is protection of the interest of the person making it. Public good is also a question of fact.

concepts.interpretation: Requires acting with due care and attention, making prior enquiry, rational basis for belief, not blind or simple belief; objective satisfaction that imputation true. Factors: circumstances, malice absence, enquiry made, care/caution, preponderance of probability.
concepts.unlisted_description: Element requiring proof of careful enquiry and absence of malice.

anchor.surface_text: This Court is Harbhajan Singh v. State of Punjab 1  in dealing with the Ninth Exception to section 499 of the Indian Penal Code said that it would have to be found out whether a person acted with due care, and attention.

concepts.interpretation: Person must show belief had rational basis; element of due care and attention; enquiry before imputation with reasons/facts indicating care and satisfaction of truth.

anchor.surface_text: The second ingredient in the Ninth Exception is that the imputation is to be made for the protection of the interest.

concepts.interpretation: Communication must be bona fide upon subject where maker has interest/duty and recipient has corresponding interest/duty. Mere pendency of proceeding or title claim does not justify defamatory imputation.
concepts.unlisted_description: Second ingredient requiring nexus to protected interest via duty.

holdings.text: Judged by these tests laid down in the rulings of this Court the findings of fact in the present case are that there is no evidence to show that before making the imputation the appellant had made any enquiry in good faith and the appellant had not shown due care and attention before making the imputation.

anchor.surface_text: Judged by these tests laid down in the rulings of this Court the findings of fact in the present case are that there is no evidence to show that before making the imputation the appellant had made any enquiry in good faith and the appellant had not shown due care and attention before making the imputation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying precedent tests from Harbhajan Singh v. State of Punjab and Chaman Lal v. State of Punjab requiring evidence of enquiry, due care, attention, and rational basis; no such evidence present.

holdings.text: By reason of the findings of fact that the appellant did not act with care and caution and secondly that the appellant was related to the respondent and thirdly that no enquiry was made by the appellant, the appellant could not claim good faith.

anchor.surface_text: By reason of the findings of fact that the appellant did not act with care and caution and secondly that the appellant was related to the respondent and thirdly that no enquiry was made by the appellant, the appellant could not claim good faith.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative factors of lack of care, familial relation, and absence of enquiry preclude good faith under Ninth Exception.

holdings.text: The second ingredient in the Ninth Exception is that the imputation is to be made for the protection of the interest. The protection of interest contemplated in the Ninth Exception is that communication must be made bonafide upon a subject in which the person making the communication has an interest or duty and the person to whom the communication is made has a corresponding interest or duty.

anchor.surface_text: The second ingredient in the Ninth Exception is that the imputation is to be made for the protection of the interest. The protection of interest contemplated in the Ninth Exception is that communication must be made bonafide upon a subject in which the person making the communication has an interest or duty and the person to whom the communication is made has a corresponding interest or duty.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of Ninth Exception requires nexus of interest or duty between communicator and recipient on the subject matter.

holdings.text: In the present case, the question was who was in possession of the land. It would not be open to a person to deny or resist possession in proceeding under section 144 of the Criminal procedure Code by hurling defamatory invectives and then claim the benefit of protection of interest.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the question was who was in possession of the land. It would not be open to a person to deny or resist possession in proceeding under section 144 of the Criminal procedure Code by hurling defamatory invectives and then claim the benefit of protection of interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 144 CrPC proceedings limited to possession; defamatory attacks on title irrelevant and unprotected by Ninth Exception.

holdings.text: Even if title is involved that by itself will not entitle a person to make a defamatory statement and then take the plea that it was for the protection of interest.

anchor.surface_text: Even if title is involved that by itself will not entitle a person to make a defamatory statement and then take the plea that it was for the protection of interest. Protection of interest of the person making the imputation will have to be established by showing that the imputation was itself the protection of interest of the person making it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Hypothetical extension of protection of interest doctrine; mere title dispute insufficient without showing imputation protects interest.

holdings.text: The High Court was justified in dismissing the revision application and not interfering with the judgment and order of the Judicial Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was justified in dismissing the revision application and not interfering with the judgment and order of the Judicial Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts correctly applied law on Ninth Exception given factual findings on good faith and protection of interest.

The protection of interest contemplated in the Ninth Exception is that communication must be made bonafide upon a subject in which the person making the communication has an interest or duty and the person to whom the communication is made has a corresponding interest or duty.
